Singing in the Dark
Singing in the Dark

I have very severe dry eyes, as a result of MCAD and Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, and that my tear ducts are literally three times larger (.45 mm) than most peopleâ€™s. With nearly no corneas, my nerve endings are exposed and suffering for it. I have no matrix for a tear film to cling to, so my tears just immediately drain and evaporate away, and MCAD has my eyes extremely inflamed all the time. Theyâ€™re always on fire.

Ketolerac didnâ€™t work for me, and Restasis (cyclosporin) can only do so much. I previously had to keep saline in covered eye cups beside my bed, and so I would have to sit up and soak my eyes a few minutes each morning before opening them, or I would tear my cornea every morning, just *trying to open my eyes, much less actually doing so. My corneas donâ€™t heal; in 2019 I had PRK surgery to cut out the scar tissue, because you canâ€™t see through it. I wish I had known about DMSO at that time, because Iâ€™m grateful for the clearer vision, but it took forever to heal from that, and now I have almost no cornea.

In February 2024I had just read about DMSO for the first time. I was desperate to get rid of the floaters I couldnâ€™t see through, and my ophthalmologist was useless in the matter. So I started adding 10% DMSO to my eye drops, (thatâ€™s one drop DMSO added to every 9 drops eye drop solution), and they all dissolved in about a month, after years of suffering with them. Encouraged, I decided to push the envelope more. Many people can tolerate 25% DMSO (1 drop out of every 4), but I canâ€™t, without corneas.

I get ridiculed for it at every bi-annual eye checkups, and spoken down to by medical eye practitioners who consider themselves eye science expertsâ€”but donâ€™t know basic high school chemistry. I have formulated my own eye drops that have brought me more relief than any sample the doctor sent home with me, whether my insurance would allow me to have it, or not.

Hyaluronic acid comes in various molecular weights: high (ex: 1500 kDa), low (ex, around 150 kDa)and ultra low (11 kDa), and is easily accessed via Amazon. (If youâ€™re curious, a Dalton is exactly one-twelfth the mass of a carbon-12 atom.) Many eye drops manufacturers that use it put in .2% weight by volume. Weight by volume (w/v) is the number of grams of the additive per 100 ml fluid. That calculates to 2 mg per ml of eye solution.

Milligram scales are easy to come by, and if you make 10 ml of eye drops, itâ€™s easier to measure out 20 mg hyaluronic acid, than it is to measure 2 mg.

I added MANY times more hyaluronic acid (HA), though. At present, I add 210 mg EACH high- and low-molecular weights hyaluronic acid. Precision is not really important here. The DMSO and HA sting, so I keep my eyes closed about 5 minutes after I put my own drops in. But the benefits are well worth it. It creates a film over my cornea, so my nerve endings arenâ€™t exposed and burning, day and night. Every time I blink, the hyaluronic acid that is under my eyelids is redistributed over my cornea. It covers my tear ducks, so I donâ€™t lose as much fluid after a blink. I donâ€™t have to keep my eyes closed and feel my way to the car, if I step outside on a windy day.

I prefer to use my cyclosporine as my base solution, but I have also formulated my eyedrops solution with regular OTC eye drops.

I use both high- and low- molecular weight hyaluronic acid (HA) because they serve different purposes. The heavier HA sits on my cornea, and provides an extra layer of protection between the nerve endings in my eyes, and this rather arid world, and the lower molecular weight HA is pulled by the DMSO between the cells, and holds the surrounding moisture between them. If I could only choose one, I would choose higher, but Iâ€™m pleased to have both.

HA takes a couple hours to dissolve, and eventually, the excess at the absurd levels I add to my formula will precipitate out of the solution. When this happens, I just add more solution to the bottle with the precipitate, for a weaker solution, and it dissolves again in a couple hours.

I ingest DMSO as well, but it has not helped my eyes. What it did help is the MCAD that swells my everything from my descending colon, down (or out), shut. DMSO tastes so nasty, though, that I have to drop it in capsules, and swallow them (a 000 capsule holds 20-30 drops, or about 1-1.5 ml DMSO). If you try this, you need to be quick: you have seconds, not minutes, because the DMSO begins to dissolve the capsules upon contact, so I do fill the capsules over a clean glass, to catch anything that I spill, in case the capsule fails.

I do look forward to going through every single one of these comments later, to see if someone else has found a way to use DMSO that could help me better than what I have come up with so far. I appreciate the time everyone has taken to share their experiences.

He was relaying a story he'd heard from another doctor, who advised a friend whose wife had a major stroke the first day of her Christmas vacation to use the DMSO the way I did. In addition, she was advised to inject it as well, but I didn't have a needle. This woman, a schoolteacher, had a stroke so severe she was on the floor, completely out. The DMSO was applied by her husband and worked so well she returned to the classroom a week or so later completely well and never told anyone about her stroke. I believe that doctor told her to do this protocol for 12 days. I only found that out later. I only did it twice for my husband, each of the two times I used it.

You are supposed to clean the skin before applying DMSO, as it is such a powerful solvent it will take anything on your skin right along with it into your body. I cleaned my hands and poured a tablespoon or so into my hands and rubbed it on my husband's scalp. (Clean the scalp, neck and underarms before applying.) Poured a little more out for the neck, more for the underarms, etc.and rubbed in with my palms. I gave him the 2 teaspoons of DMSO in distilled water the doctor in the article recommended to the woman with a stroke. I used a glass drinking cup, rather than plastic.

Hope this helps, and that I haven't misrepresented anything. I read the article a while back.

A Midwestern Doctor
2d

I seem to recall (but can't find the source) that one of the really old antipsychotics was potentiated by DMSO. However, outside of that, issues have not been reported. That said, it's advised to have them at least 2 hours apart.

Regarding the actual condition, there is some data that DMSO will treat schitzophrenia and psychosis (when it was done it was intermuscularly, so it would probably need to be oral) and that it is also very helpful for people wanting to withdraw from drugs or stop using psyche meds. However, in this case, there are so many variables it's nearly impossible to know if it would help. If you stop the meds, you have to gradually taper them rather than go cold turkey, and deciding if and when that's appropraite to do (based on how he is and how other things change his situation) will be a complex process lots of people will need to be consulted on.

sorry to hear that. I have a couple of issues in my right knee--chondromalacia of the patella and a meniscal tear 20 years ago-- and I very much want to avoid a replacement. So I use DMSO on the knee quite often. Within the last year or so, I've taken up trail running (more walking than running for someone at my age). Sometimes during my outings I can feel the right knee is not quite "right", but DSMO has kept it reasonably sound, and maybe it's in even better shape now that it was a year ago. Many believe that running is hard on the knees, but it's my belief and experience that if your technique is correct, it's not hard on the knees and may actually be beneficial. (Correct technique is quickly developed by running barefoot on soft or grassy surface). I couldn't have continued with the trail running without DMSO!
